segment.source: Microsoft Surface Enterprise Management Mode
segment.target: Microsoft Surface Enterprise Management Mode

segment.source: Microsoft Surface Enterprise Management Mode (SEMM) is a feature of Surface devices with Surface UEFI that allows you to secure and manage firmware settings within your organization.
segment.target: Microsoft Surface Enterprise Management Mode (SEMM) is a feature of Surface devices with Surface UEFI that allows you to secure and manage firmware settings within your organization.

segment.source: With SEMM, IT professionals can prepare configurations of UEFI settings and install them on a Surface device.
segment.target: With SEMM, IT professionals can prepare configurations of UEFI settings and install them on a Surface device.

segment.source: In addition to the ability to configure UEFI settings, SEMM also uses a certificate to protect the configuration from unauthorized tampering or removal.
segment.target: In addition to the ability to configure UEFI settings, SEMM also uses a certificate to protect the configuration from unauthorized tampering or removal.

segment.source: Note:SEMM is only available on devices with Surface UEFI firmware, such as Surface Pro 4 and Surface Book.
segment.target: Note:SEMM is only available on devices with Surface UEFI firmware, such as Surface Pro 4 and Surface Book.

segment.source: For more information about Surface UEFI, see Manage Surface UEFI Settings.
segment.target: For more information about Surface UEFI, see Manage Surface UEFI Settings.

segment.source: When Surface devices are configured by SEMM and secured with the SEMM certificate, they are considered enrolled in SEMM.
segment.target: When Surface devices are configured by SEMM and secured with the SEMM certificate, they are considered enrolled in SEMM.

segment.source: When the SEMM certificate is removed and control of UEFI settings is returned to the user of the device, the Surface device is considered unenrolled in SEMM.
segment.target: When the SEMM certificate is removed and control of UEFI settings is returned to the user of the device, the Surface device is considered unenrolled in SEMM.

segment.source: Microsoft Surface UEFI Configurator
segment.target: Microsoft Surface UEFI Configurator

segment.source: The primary workspace of SEMM is Microsoft Surface UEFI Configurator, as shown in Figure 1.
segment.target: The primary workspace of SEMM is Microsoft Surface UEFI Configurator, as shown in Figure 1.

segment.source: Microsoft Surface UEFI Configurator is a tool that is used to create Windows Installer (.msi) packages that are used to enroll, configure, and unenroll SEMM on a Surface device.
segment.target: Microsoft Surface UEFI Configurator is a tool that is used to create Windows Installer (.msi) packages that are used to enroll, configure, and unenroll SEMM on a Surface device.

segment.source: These packages contain a configuration file where the settings for UEFI are specified.
segment.target: These packages contain a configuration file where the settings for UEFI are specified.

segment.source: SEMM packages also contain a certificate that is installed and stored in firmware and used to verify the signature of configuration files before UEFI settings are applied.
segment.target: SEMM packages also contain a certificate that is installed and stored in firmware and used to verify the signature of configuration files before UEFI settings are applied.

segment.source: Configuration package
segment.target: Configuration package

segment.source: Surface UEFI configuration packages are the primary mechanism to implement and manage SEMM on Surface devices.
segment.target: Surface UEFI configuration packages are the primary mechanism to implement and manage SEMM on Surface devices.

segment.source: These packages contain a configuration file of UEFI settings specified during creation of the package in Microsoft Surface UEFI Configurator and a certificate file, as shown in Figure 2.
segment.target: These packages contain a configuration file of UEFI settings specified during creation of the package in Microsoft Surface UEFI Configurator and a certificate file, as shown in Figure 2.

segment.source: When a configuration package is run for the first time on a Surface device that is not already enrolled in SEMM, it provisions the certificate file in the device’s firmware and enrolls the device in SEMM.
segment.target: When a configuration package is run for the first time on a Surface device that is not already enrolled in SEMM, it provisions the certificate file in the device’s firmware and enrolls the device in SEMM.

segment.source: When enrolling a device in SEMM, you will be prompted to confirm the operation by providing the last two digits of the SEMM certificate thumbprint before the certificate file is stored and the enrollment can complete.
segment.target: When enrolling a device in SEMM, you will be prompted to confirm the operation by providing the last two digits of the SEMM certificate thumbprint before the certificate file is stored and the enrollment can complete.

segment.source: This confirmation requires that a user be present at the device at the time of enrollment to perform the confirmation.
segment.target: This confirmation requires that a user be present at the device at the time of enrollment to perform the confirmation.

segment.source: After a device is enrolled in SEMM, the configuration file is read and the settings specified in the file are applied to UEFI.
segment.target: After a device is enrolled in SEMM, the configuration file is read and the settings specified in the file are applied to UEFI.

segment.source: When you run a configuration package on a device that is already enrolled in SEMM, the signature of the configuration file is checked against the certificate that is stored in the device firmware.
segment.target: When you run a configuration package on a device that is already enrolled in SEMM, the signature of the configuration file is checked against the certificate that is stored in the device firmware.

segment.source: If the signature does not match, no changes are applied to the device.
segment.target: If the signature does not match, no changes are applied to the device.

segment.source: Reset package
segment.target: Reset package

segment.source: A Surface UEFI reset package is used to perform only one task — to unenroll a Surface device from SEMM.
segment.target: A Surface UEFI reset package is used to perform only one task — to unenroll a Surface device from SEMM.

segment.source: The reset package contains signed instructions to remove the SEMM certificate from the device’s firmware and to reset UEFI settings to factory default.
segment.target: The reset package contains signed instructions to remove the SEMM certificate from the device’s firmware and to reset UEFI settings to factory default.

segment.source: Like a Surface UEFI configuration package, a reset package must be signed with the same SEMM certificate that is provisioned on the Surface device.
segment.target: Like a Surface UEFI configuration package, a reset package must be signed with the same SEMM certificate that is provisioned on the Surface device.

segment.source: When you create a SEMM reset package, you are required to supply the serial number of the Surface device you intend to reset.
segment.target: When you create a SEMM reset package, you are required to supply the serial number of the Surface device you intend to reset.

segment.source: SEMM reset packages are not universal and are specific to one device.
segment.target: SEMM reset packages are not universal and are specific to one device.

segment.source: Recovery request
segment.target: Recovery request

segment.source: In some scenarios, it may be impossible to use a Surface UEFI reset package.
segment.target: In some scenarios, it may be impossible to use a Surface UEFI reset package.

segment.source: (For example, if Windows becomes unusable on the Surface device.) In these scenarios you can unenroll the Surface device from SEMM through the Enterprise Management page of Surface UEFI (shown in Figure 7) with a Recovery Request operation.
segment.target: (For example, if Windows becomes unusable on the Surface device.) In these scenarios you can unenroll the Surface device from SEMM through the Enterprise Management page of Surface UEFI (shown in Figure 7) with a Recovery Request operation.

segment.source: When you use the process on the Enterprise Management page to reset SEMM on a Surface device, you are provided with a Reset Request.
segment.target: When you use the process on the Enterprise Management page to reset SEMM on a Surface device, you are provided with a Reset Request.

segment.source: This Reset Request can be saved as a file to a USB drive, copied as text, or read as a QR Code with a mobile device to be easily emailed or messaged.
segment.target: This Reset Request can be saved as a file to a USB drive, copied as text, or read as a QR Code with a mobile device to be easily emailed or messaged.

segment.source: Use the Microsoft Surface UEFI Configurator Reset Request option to load a Reset Request file or enter the Reset Request text or QR Code.
segment.target: Use the Microsoft Surface UEFI Configurator Reset Request option to load a Reset Request file or enter the Reset Request text or QR Code.

segment.source: Microsoft Surface UEFI Configurator will generate a verification code that can be entered on the Surface device.
segment.target: Microsoft Surface UEFI Configurator will generate a verification code that can be entered on the Surface device.

segment.source: If you enter the code on the Surface device and click Restart, the device will be unenrolled from SEMM.
segment.target: If you enter the code on the Surface device and click Restart, the device will be unenrolled from SEMM.

segment.source: Note:A Reset Request expires two hours after it is created.
segment.target: Note:A Reset Request expires two hours after it is created.

segment.source: Surface Enterprise Management Mode certificate requirements
segment.target: Surface Enterprise Management Mode certificate requirements

segment.source: Note:The SEMM certificate is required to perform any modification to SEMM or Surface UEFI settings on enrolled Surface devices.
segment.target: Note:The SEMM certificate is required to perform any modification to SEMM or Surface UEFI settings on enrolled Surface devices.

segment.source: If the SEMM certificate is corrupted or lost, SEMM cannot be removed or reset.
segment.target: If the SEMM certificate is corrupted or lost, SEMM cannot be removed or reset.

segment.source: Manage your SEMM certificate accordingly with an appropriate solution for backup and recovery.
segment.target: Manage your SEMM certificate accordingly with an appropriate solution for backup and recovery.

segment.source: Packages created with the Microsoft Surface UEFI Configurator tool are signed with a certificate.
segment.target: Packages created with the Microsoft Surface UEFI Configurator tool are signed with a certificate.

segment.source: This certificate ensures that after a device is enrolled in SEMM, only packages created with the approved certificate can be used to modify the settings of UEFI.
segment.target: This certificate ensures that after a device is enrolled in SEMM, only packages created with the approved certificate can be used to modify the settings of UEFI.

segment.source: The following settings are recommended for the SEMM certificate:
segment.target: The following settings are recommended for the SEMM certificate:

segment.source: Key Algorithm – RSA
segment.target: Key Algorithm – RSA

segment.source: Key Length – 2048
segment.target: Key Length – 2048

segment.source: Hash Algorithm – SHA-256
segment.target: Hash Algorithm – SHA-256

segment.source: Type – SSL Server Authentication
segment.target: Type – SSL Server Authentication

segment.source: Key Usage – Key Encipherment
segment.target: Key Usage – Key Encipherment

segment.source: Provider – Microsoft Enhanced RSA and AES Cryptographic Provider
segment.target: Provider – Microsoft Enhanced RSA and AES Cryptographic Provider

segment.source: Expiration Date – 15 Months from certificate creation
segment.target: Expiration Date – 15 Months from certificate creation

segment.source: Key Export Policy – Exportable
segment.target: Key Export Policy – Exportable

segment.source: It is also recommended that the SEMM certificate be authenticated in a two-tier public key infrastructure (PKI) architecture where the intermediate certification authority (CA) is dedicated to SEMM, enabling certificate revocation.
segment.target: It is also recommended that the SEMM certificate be authenticated in a two-tier public key infrastructure (PKI) architecture where the intermediate certification authority (CA) is dedicated to SEMM, enabling certificate revocation.

segment.source: For more information about a two-tier PKI configuration, see Test Lab Guide: Deploying an AD CS Two-Tier PKI Hierarchy.
segment.target: For more information about a two-tier PKI configuration, see Test Lab Guide: Deploying an AD CS Two-Tier PKI Hierarchy.
